review.title: A computer program for simulating time travel and a possible 'solution' for the grandfather paradox
review.abstract: While the possibility of time travel in physics is still debated, the explosive growth of virtual-reality simulations opens up new possibilities to rigorously explore such time travel and its consequences in the digital domain. Here we provide a computational model of time travel and a computer program that allows exploring digital time travel. In order to explain our method we formalize a simplified version of the famous grandfather paradox, show how the system can allow the participant to go back in time, try to kill their ancestors before they were born, and experience the consequences. The system has even come up with scenarios that can be considered consistent "solutions" of the grandfather paradox. We discuss the conditions for digital time travel, which indicate that it has a large number of practical applications.

sections.heading: 2.1 Logic
sections.text: The biggest challenge in providing a digital time experience is the automatic tracking of causality chains. Fortunately, there are abundant formalizations and techniques in arithmetic logic and artificial intelligence that can be used to track causality. We have opted for the Boolean spread of limitations; this is a simple mechanism we have used in the past for automated thinking related to VR applications. Units in this layer are terms, facts and limitations. The terms in our grandfather paradox are mainly people and actions (supplementary text, p. 1). Facts are functions or actions that are applied to other terms. Exactly one of the terms must denote the current time to which the fact applies. At any given moment, facts are assigned to one of three truth values: truth value, false or unknown.

referenceMentions.context: An early discussion of time travel in philosophy in contemporary times has been provided by Lewis (Lewis 1976).

Horwich (Horwich 1975) criticized this view by pointing out that if travel to the local past is allowed then there would be countless attempts to initiate self-defeating causal chains, and it would be highly improbable that all of them would be avoided by mundane events such as slipping over a banana peel.
So far we have adopted the formal way, which is more convenient from an algorithmic point of view would adopt a metatemporal viewpoint ("the view from nowhen" (Price 1996)).

A person and their clone have the same personal identity in the same way that a child and the same person who is a grownup have the same personal identity (see (Lewis 1976) for a discussion on identity and time travel) (Section S.

Since we allow changing history, our interpretation is similar to Deutsch's interpretation of experiencing time travel in parallel universes through virtual reality (Deutsch 1997), but there are subtle differences; for example, in the first time around our time traveler does not need to meet his future clone.
